Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44283 
Regional Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Comparative Infrastructure Development Assessment 
of the Kingdom of Thailand and the Republic of Korea 
 
(Financed by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Directors General  K. Senga, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
K. Gerhaeusser, East Asia Department 
Country Director  C.M. Steffensen, Thailand Resident Mission, SERD 
Director  A.J. Jude, Energy and Water Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  R. Kausar, Infrastructure Specialist, SERD

O. Jetwattana, Private Sector Economics Officer, SERD 
S. N. Oh, Principal Country Economist, SERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) discussed with the National Economic and Social 
Development  Board  under  the  Office  of  the  Prime  Minister  of  Thailand  and  the  Thailand 
Development Research Institute the need to undertake an infrastructure assessment technical 
assistance (TA) in the Kingdom of Thailand with two aims. The first is to quickly review the 
infrastructure development that Thailand has achieved in key infrastructure subsectors such as 
power, roads, and water supply and its plans for the future, including in particular the role of 
private sector investment in infrastructure projects. The second is to understand what lessons 
Thailand’s infrastructure development have for emerging middle-income countries, as well as for 
Thailand's  own  prospective  investments  in  infrastructure.  In  2009,  Thailand  enjoyed  an 
infrastructure quality index rank of 29, compared with Indonesia at 86, the Philippines at 92, and 
Viet Nam at 93.1 Similarly, the Republic of Korea ranks at 15 but has a global competitiveness 
index of 13, compared with Thailand at 34.2 Considering that the Republic of Korea is a leading 
and sizeable developing member country as well as a member of the Organization for Economic 
Co-operation  and  Development,  a  comparative  assessment  of  the  Republic  of  Korea  with 
Thailand  will  help  understand  what  importance  the  Republic  of  Korea  has  placed  on 
infrastructure development and what lessons Thailand can apply from its experience to take the 
country to the next level of development.  
 
2.  The economic growth and improving competitiveness of both Thailand and the Republic 
of Korea has been underpinned to some extent by significant infrastructure development. The 
diverse  and  rich  development  experiences  of  these  two  countries  emanate  from  their 
differences in economic policies and systems, dissimilarities in their institutions, and cultural and 
social diversity. Although there are significant gaps between the infrastructure capacities of both 
countries as seen by global indicators, Thailand has made significant progress compared with 
some of its regional neighbors and currently ranks second in Southeast Asia only to Malaysia, 
which has a global competitiveness index of 21 and an infrastructure quality index of 23. A 
comparative assessment between Thailand and the Republic of Korea will help to understand 
the enabling environment for the development of infrastructure and also review (i) infrastructure 
investment-led growth, (ii) the relationship between fiscal discipline and infrastructure spending, 
(iii) the impact of urban infrastructure development, (iv) the role of local and central government 
in infrastructure provision, (v) the participation of private sector and foreign investors, and (vi) 
the financing of infrastructure development. Lessons from an exercise of this nature can create 
a useful body of knowledge for Thailand and other developing and emerging Asian economies. 
Prior  to  undertaking  a  comparative  assessment,  the  existing  literature  on  infrastructure 
development  and  the  success  of  both  countries  will  be  analyzed  to  ensure  that  the  TA 
contributes something new. The TA will closely synergize its efforts with a separate TA on 
mainstreaming  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs)  in Thailand.3 The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Asia's infrastructure gaps are serious because of the continent’s rising urban populations; 
growing incomes; rapid industrialization; and burgeoning demand for energy, water, and mobility. 
                                                
1  ADB and ADB Institute. 2009. Infrastructure for a Seamless Asia. Manila. 
2  World Economic Forum (2008). 
3  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Thailand for Mainstreaming Public–Private Partnerships. 
Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 October 2010.

2   
A  recent  study,  Infrastructure  for  a  Seamless  Asia  (footnote  1),  estimates  that  Asia's 
infrastructure investment needs could be as high as $8 trillion by 2020. Resources of this order 
are always in short supply, and the recent global financial turmoil and resulting reduction in 
private investment have made matters worse. Asia's future development is crucially linked to 
infrastructure. Developing bankable projects, finding resources, and building capacity for design, 
delivery, and operation remain daunting tasks.  
 
4.  Against this backdrop, a distillation of the experience of some of the other countries in 
Asia, and of the region in general, over the past 50 years suggests that the sustainability of 
infrastructure  development  is  an  issue.  In  the  delicate  balance  between  affordability  and 
economic growth, systems that depend on fossil fuels (e.g., coal-fired power plants and urban 
transport systems that rely heavily on private cars) have led the way in many parts of Asia. 
There  are  cases  where  emphasis  is  on  inefficient,  traditional  technologies  which  deny 
opportunities of leapfrogging to the next generation of technologies. A sustainable approach is 
founded on the notion of "smart growth." Environmental sustainability, characterized as low 
energy, carbon, and water intensity, is a key to inclusive development that will improve access 
to services for all sections of the population, including the rural and urban poor. 
 
5.  Planning for infrastructure development in Asia requires a nuanced view of the region. 
Asia is not homogeneous, and neither are the development contexts or needs of its constituent 
countries.  Basic  energy  and  transport  infrastructure  are  needed  by  South  Asia  and  most 
countries in the Greater Mekong Subregion. The People’s Republic of China is further ahead in 
this respect and is developing an exemplary network of high-speed railway systems to enhance 
national economic integration. Elsewhere, such as in the Republic of Korea and Malaysia, 
resources and capacity building are needed to maintain and upgrade existing infrastructure. A 
common thread that runs across this nuanced view is that the public sector can no longer be the 
principal infrastructure financier. Private capital and expertise have to be maximally leveraged.  
 
6.  Financing Asia's infrastructure is a complex issue. All countries prepare medium to long 
term development plans and strategies for the key sectors of energy, transport, and water 
supply but they do not always come to fruition. The public sector has problems of constrained 
access to funds, lack of competition, and governance and corruption issues further complicate 
the  picture.  Private  sector  investors  prefer  to  prioritize  low-risk  countries.  The  lack  of  a 
transparent  and  consistent  regulatory  environment  and  a  paucity  of  resources  and  policy 
support measures to meet the standards of global best practice further complicate matters. 
Land  acquisition  can  be  challenging  when  large-scale  projects  are  involved.  Untraditional 
financing, such as pension funds, early support mechanisms, and sovereign investment funds 
that support various investments, partial government subsidies that buy down project risk such 
as the "viability-gap funding" provided in India and the Indonesia Infrastructure Finance Facility, 
which when operational will provide long tenor project financing, are some of the several options 
for promoting infrastructure financing.  
 
7.  Much of the Republic of Korea's economic growth was centered on policies which called 
for extensive infrastructure development. Beginning in the mid-1960s, the country focused on 
railway  and  highway  projects.  In  the  1970s,  however,  as  the  country  approached  full 
employment,  bottlenecks  became  apparent.  Emphasis  then  shifted  to  heavy  industry  and 
chemicals, followed by telecommunications. In parallel, investments in deepwater ports were 
added to the ongoing investments in roads and railways. Infrastructure spending has averaged 
8% of gross domestic product (GDP), most notably for telecommunications and broadband 
internet  access.  This  enables  a  leadership  position  in  the  knowledge  economy.  However, 
private investments have not been forthcoming to the fullest extent, and the Government of the

3                       
Republic of Korea is currently experimenting with new, far-reaching reforms to leverage private 
financing  and  also  include  enhancing  the  use  of  information  technology  systems  and  e-
commerce to facilitate project transactions. 
 
8.  In light of this, it is instructive to learn from the infrastructure success story of the 
Republic of Korea. During the Asian financial crisis of 1997–1998, infrastructure programs were 
among the first to be cut in developing economies such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and 
Thailand—and to a much lesser extent in the Republic of Korea. As soon as the economy 
began to bounce back in the Republic of Korea, the government increased investment to pre-
crisis levels to create jobs and stimulate the economy. Thailand also has built high-quality roads 
and energy and telecoms infrastructure. While road and electricity coverage have risen to 99%, 
some gaps exist in the quality of service delivery, management, and sector regulation. There 
are also imbalances in the transport connectivity mix, with roads outstripping railways by a 
significant margin which continue to under perform and unable to complement road networks. 
The State Railway of Thailand has accumulated more than $2 billion in debts, which adds to the 
difficult financial condition of the sector. The country’s key infrastructure sectors such as energy 
and transport remain hostage to volatile global oil prices. As for water supply on the other hand, 
only 60% of the country's urban centers are covered by the services of a metropolitan or 
provincial water authority. The quality of service in the other 40% is largely poor, ranging up to 
fair and further work is required to connect more households and improve service delivery levels.  
 
9.  The private sector has had a lesser role in meeting Thailand's infrastructure needs than 
in many of its neighbors, with only telecommunications and energy experiencing sustained 
investment. As in other countries in Asia, the telecoms sector in Thailand has shown good 
progress in terms of expanding access with the entry of new service providers backed up by a 
strong regulator. Similarly, another important step in PPPs was the first round of independent 
power producers bidding in 1994, with six companies receiving contracts for power generation. 
The 1990s also saw private participation in the water and sanitation sector to a limited extent, 
including lease and management contracts from metropolitan and provincial water authorities. 
 
10.  Out  of  the  three  concessions  granted  in  1990s  for  mass  rapid  transit  projects  in 
metropolitan Bangkok, only one, for the Green Line, was implemented. The Mass Rapid Transit 
Authority was later established, in 1992, to take over rail transit from the Expressway Transit 
Authority. After the Asian financial crisis, in 2000, another concession was granted for the 
operation and maintenance of the Blue Line. Ridership for both mass rapid transit projects has 
been below forecast, which is not unusual for such projects. However, ridership has also been 
adversely affected by the failure to integrate the two systems with each other—either physically 
or for ticketing—or with the public bus network. Expressway projects in Bangkok have faced 
problems with land acquisition and the enforcement of contractually agreed tolls. Similarly, the 
port sector faces challenges, as the government wishes to develop a deepwater harbor in 
western Thailand to facilitate exports to Europe and elsewhere but faces strong resistance from 
the local people.  
 
11.  Although many factors account for a country’s competitiveness in the global economy, 
the provision of adequate infrastructure is constantly cited as a key pillar to encourage private 
investment  and  enhance  economic  growth.  Prior  to  the  Asian  financial  crisis,  government 
investment alone was as high as 10% of GDP in Thailand but has since slipped to less than 
5%.5 Subsequently, private investment in infrastructure projects also declined as a percentage 
                                                
5 In countries such as Thailand and Indonesia, it is widely accepted that to achieve reasonable figures of economic 
growth of 6% or higher, governments should spend at least 5% of their GDP on infrastructure development.

4   
of  GDP—as  it  has  across  the  region.  The  current  Tenth  National  Economic  and  Social 
Development Plan, 2007–2011 and the proposed 11th plan for 2012–2016 stress infrastructure 
development as a national priority to enhance Thailand’s competitiveness and support long-term 
growth. Thailand’s medium-term infrastructure investment program is a positive first step toward 
closing the widening gap in infrastructure investment. A major policy initiative is to promote 
economic  growth  through  infrastructure  development  over  the  medium-term,  and  the 
government is keen to consider alternative modes of financing infrastructure and inviting private 
participation under PPP.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA's impact will be lessons learned for enhancing infrastructure provision in the key 
sectors of energy, transport, and water supply for developing member countries in Asia. The 
TA's outcome will be a comparative assessment of Thailand and the Republic of Korea on their 
infrastructure development in energy, transport, and water supply.  
   
B.    Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The key output of this TA is a comparative assessment of infrastructure development in 
Thailand and the Republic of Korea to identify a range of lessons and good practices and an 
analysis of the adequacy and effectiveness of policy measures in the two countries and the 
distributional  impacts  of  infrastructure  development  on  different  sectors.  The  TA  will  be 
monitored  through  regular  reporting,  building  consensus  with  workshops,  and  soliciting 
comments and suggestions from key stakeholders. It will include an inception workshop in 
Thailand one month after consultants have been mobilized. A series of smaller workshops will 
be held to discuss the development and the progress of the TA with the National Economic and 
Social Development Board (NESDB), the Thailand Development Research Institute (TDRI), and 
the Ministry of Strategy and Finance of the Republic of Korea. In Thailand, NESDB and TDRI 
are the main infrastructure think tanks of the country.  
 
14.  The  assumptions  for  undertaking  the  TA  are  (i)  the  final  report  is  accepted  by 
counterparts in Thailand and the Republic of Korea, (ii) government counterparts provide the 
necessary  support  to  the  consultant  teams,  and  (iii)  strong  ownership  by  the  government 
counterparts themselves. The risks are (i) the lessons learned are not accepted by Thailand or 
the Republic of Korea, (ii) change of government’s mindset, and (iii) excessively broad demand 
for study scope during implementation of the TA.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The cost of the TA is $640,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, to be administered by ADB. 
The Government of the Republic of Korea will finance, through the Ministry of Strategy and 
Finance,  a  further  $200,000  in  contributions  in  kind  and  in  cash,  and  the  Government  of 
Thailand will finance $40,000 with in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.

5                       
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency, with the Southeast Asia Department (SERD) and the 
East  Asia  Department  (EARD)  as  focal  points.  The  TA  will  coordinate  with  the  regional 
departments as appropriate for communication and consultation with counterparts in Thailand 
and the Republic of Korea.  
 
17.  The TA will require 12 person-months of international consulting services and 12 person-
months  of  national  consulting  services.  To  ensure  a  diverse  array  of  skill  sets,  individual 
consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. To successfully implement this TA, one SERD professional staff member and one 
operations  assistant  will  consolidate  consultants'  outputs  and  coordinate  and  administer 
consultant contracts. SERD and EARD will review the outputs, which may be disseminated by 
website publication, in-country workshops, electronic reports, and other means to be specified in 
a knowledge dissemination action plan. ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from  time  to  time)  will  be  applicable  for  assets  purchased  for  the  project,  which,  upon 
completion, will be handed over to selected government agencies or disposed of in accordance 
with ADB procedures. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.    THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  for  the 
Comparative  Infrastructure  Development  Assessment  of  the  Kingdom  of  Thailand  and  the 
Republic of Korea, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Terms of Reference 
 
1.  The terms of reference for international consultants on the Comparative Infrastructure 
Development Assessment of the Kingdom of Thailand and the Republic of Korea stipulate that 
the  work  plan  is  subject  to  refinement  before  and  during  implementation  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The work plan of national consultants may also be refined, based on 
the needs of the international consultants and ADB. Further, all team members are requested to 
assist ADB with related activities and engage in consultations with stakeholders as appropriate. 
The consulting  services  may  be  provided  intermittently,  based  on  agreement  between  the 
consultants and ADB.  
 
B.  Infrastructure Specialist and Team Leader (one international, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultant will support ADB in producing the outputs of the technical assistance 
(TA), oversee the work of the other consultants, and recommend adjustments in the team's work 
program as required. Working intermittently, he or she will assist ADB in administering the TA 
and  activities,  including  procurement,  and  provide  technical  inputs  as  the  infrastructure 
specialist. The consultant's tasks will include the following:  
(i)  During the inception phase of the TA in the first month, draft a time-bound work 
program for the other members of the TA, to be reviewed by ADB.  
(ii)  Undertake  a  review  of  existing  infrastructure  documentation  available  for 
Thailand  and  the  Republic  of  Korea  to  generate  new  lessons  and 
recommendations. 
(iii)  In the assessment of the Republic of Korea, identify why it has achieved higher 
development and what lessons to draw, which can later be applied to middle-
income countries such as Thailand, and explain whether the rate of growth of 
infrastructure was led by demand or created demand. 
(iv)  Assess Thailand's strategic infrastructure planning objectives for the Eleventh 
National Plan, 2012–2016 in energy, transport, and water supply. 
(v)  Find instances of private sector success, if any, in energy, transport, or water 
supply and present them as box stories in the final report. 
(vi)  Assess  the  Government  of  Thailand’s  key  considerations  for  long-term 
infrastructure planning, including a review of Article 67 of the Thai Constitution, 
which  highlights  the  importance  of  fully  engaging  all  stakeholders  and  the 
surrounding community for proposed infrastructure projects undertaken by the 
government and/or the private sector, focusing particularly on their impact on 
health and the environment. 
(vii)  With the TA team, coordinate with the Thailand Development Research Institute 
and/or the Korea Development Institute to meet data and survey requirements as 
necessary. 
(viii)  Organize workshops and dissemination activities with the assistance of other 
team members to raise awareness of the comparative infrastructure assessment 
and  attract  the  participation  of key  stakeholders from  the  public  and  private 
sectors and civil society. 
(ix)  Coordinate and discuss the TA outcomes with other teams undertaking similar 
infrastructure-related  technical  assistance,  such  as  the  Public–Private 
Partnership Development in Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines

10      Appendix 3   
 
East ASEAN Growth Area and Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle 
and other similar ADB-financed activities. 
 
3.  The consultant should have at least 15 years of relevant professional and technical 
experience in infrastructure and international experience in development projects in Asia. An 
advanced degree in economics and/or public policy is preferred.  
 
C.  Sector Specialists for Energy, Transport, and Water Supply (one international per 
sector, 2 person-months each; and one Thai national per sector in Thailand, 4 person-
months each) 
 
4.  The sector specialists will provide sector technical inputs as required for the TA toward 
preparing the comparative assessment of the infrastructure sector in Thailand and the Republic 
of Korea. They will work, possibly intermittently if required, under the supervision of the team 
leader. The consultants’ tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Undertake a literature review of infrastructure development and lessons learned 
in both Thailand and the Republic of Korea in the respective sectors and provide 
inputs to the team leader. 
(ii)  Review the availability of government sector strategies and national development 
plans for long-term planning and large-scale investment decisions. 
(iii)  Provide a general assessment of sector development and its distribution across 
the country. 
(iv)  In the water supply sector, identify the main reasons for low levels of service in 
many parts of Thailand and propose ways to overcome the deficiencies. 
(v)  Assess the private sector's role in the each sector and prepare a broad overview 
of public versus private investments in each.  
(vi)  Identify the role of foreign investment, if any, and possible sector contributions. 
(vii)  Prepare brief reports by sector toward the comparative analysis of Thailand and 
the Republic of Korea and summarize the similarities and differences. 
(viii)  Generate a short report on lessons from the experience in the Republic of Korea 
that  can  be  applied  to  Thailand  and  other  developing  member  countries  in 
Southeast Asia. 
 
5.  International  experts  will  have  at  least  7  years  of  international  experience  in  the 
respective  infrastructure  sectors,  and  the  national  experts  will  have  at  least  3  years.  The 
international experience of the international experts will typically have been accumulated in both 
developing and developed economies. Both international and national experts should be able to 
demonstrate experience of undertaking similar sector work in the past. The national consultants’ 
work will be entirely in Thailand. The international experts will cover both countries. 
 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
 
6.  The consultants will submit the following reports: 
(i)  the inception report (1 month after the commencement of services), presenting 
initial findings and describing the operational approach and the work program;  
(ii)  the  first  interim report  (4  months after  the  commencement  of  services), 
presenting  preliminary  findings  and  recommendations  and  proposing 
modifications, if any, in the study program during the remaining period;  
(iii)  the draft final report (7 months after the commencement of services), describing 
in  detail  the  work  undertaken  and  presenting  the  study  conclusions  and 
recommendations; and

(iv)  the final report (8 months after the commencement of services), incorporating 
comments received on the draft final report.
